GameDBLocalizedString.Text: 光線角化症
光線角化症は、長年日光にさらされることによって発症する、皮膚のざらざらした鱗状の斑点です。
皮膚上の結節
皮膚に小さな光沢のある隆起や結節ができています。
傍神経浸潤
傍神経浸潤（PNI）とは、神経の周囲にがんが浸潤している状態を指します。
転移性がん
転移性がんとは、発生した部位から体の他の部位に転移するがんです。
慢性創傷
慢性創傷とは、3ヶ月程度で治らない傷のことです。最初は小さく、何度もかさぶたになることもありますが、自然に治癒しない状態を指します。
異常なほくろ
ほくろの境目が不均一で、色が変わっていたり、生え方が変化しています。
High Epinephrine Levels
患者のエピネフリン（アドレナリン）の血中濃度が上昇しています。アドレナリンは通常、副腎と延髄にある少数の神経細胞の両方によって産生されます。
ノルエピネフリン血中濃度の上昇
患者のノルエピネフリン（ノルアドレナリン）の血中濃度が上昇しています。ノルエピネフリンは体内で自然に発生する化学物質で、ストレスホルモンと神経伝達物質の両方の働きをします。脳がストレスとなる出来事が起こったと認識すると、ストレスホルモンとして血中に放出されます。
発作
発作とは、突然、脳の中で制御不能な電気的障害が起こることです。発作が起きると、行動、動作、感情、意識レベルが変化することがあります。
軽度の喀血
喀血とは、気管支、喉頭、気管、肺から血液や血液の混じった粘液が咳き込むこと、つまり、気道から出血することです。肺がん、結核、気管支炎、肺炎などの感染症、ある種の心疾患などで起こることがあります。
術後神経障害性疼痛
手術中に神経を損傷した場合、術後神経障害性疼痛（PONP）を発症することがあります。損傷した神経は、体の各部位から脳へ信号を正しく伝えることができません。その代わりに、これらの信号が誇張され、数ヶ月から数年にわたり慢性的な痛みが続くことがあります。
癌胎児性抗原(CEA)血中濃度の上昇
癌胎児性抗原(CEA)の血中濃度が上昇している患者さんです。CEAの高値は、ある種の癌の徴候である可能性があります。これには、結腸および直腸、前立腺、卵巣、肺、甲状腺、または肝臓のがんなどが含まれます。また、肝硬変、非がん性乳房疾患、肺気腫など、がん以外の疾患の徴候として認められる場合もあります。
Colorectal Polyp
ポリープとは、結腸や直腸の粘膜にできた組織の増殖で、腸の中に突出しているものをいいます。大腸ポリープのある人には、通常は自覚症状が全くありません。ほとんどの大腸ポリープは無害ですが、中には癌化するものもあります。
低ナトリウム血症
低ナトリウム血症は、血液中のナトリウムの濃度が異常に低くなった場合に起こります。ナトリウムは電解質の一種で、細胞の中や周りにある水の量を調節する働きがあります。
高血糖
高血糖とは、専門用語で「血糖値が高い」ことを意味します。高血糖は、体内のインスリンの量が少なすぎるか、インスリンをうまく使えない場合に起こります。
高コルチゾール症
高コルチゾール症はクッシング症候群とも呼ばれ、副腎から自然に分泌されるホルモンであるコルチゾールが体内の組織で慢性的に過剰なレベルに晒されることによって起こるまれな内分泌疾患です。
アルドステロン症
アルドステロン症は、副腎で作られるアルドステロンが過剰になり、高血圧や血中カリウム濃度の低下を引き起こす病気です。原発性アルドステロン症は、片方の副腎の機能亢進（片側性疾患）と両方の副腎（両側性疾患）のいずれかが原因となって発症することがあります。
リンパ節炎
リンパ節炎（腫脹性リンパ節）とは、病気や感染症、ストレスなどに反応して、リンパ節が腫れることをいいます。リンパ節の腫れは、リンパ系が原因物質を体外に排出しようとする働きがあることを示す一つのサインです。通常、免疫系腺は細菌やウイルス感染に反応して拡大しますが、多くのリンパ節が突然腫れることは、がんを示唆している可能性があります。
尿中の5-HIAA濃度の上昇
患者の尿中の5-HIAA（5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid）濃度が上昇しています。5ヒドロキシインドール酢酸（5HIAA）は、尿中のセロトニンの代謝産物として測定されます。5HIAAの上昇は、カルチノイド症候群と相関があります。心臓弁が高濃度のセロトニンに長時間さらされることは、本疾患の合併症と関連します。
クロモグラニンA血中濃度が上昇
患者さんの血液中の腫瘍マーカーであるクロモグラニンAの濃度が上昇しています。クロモグラニンA（CgA）は、すべてのカルチノイド腫瘍に関連する一般的なマーカーであり、腫瘍細胞によって産生され、放出されるタンパク質です。クロモグラニンAは他のホルモンと関連し、その調節に関与している可能性があります。血中のクロモグラニンAには正常値があり、現在のところ、おおよそ39ng/L以下の範囲となっています。
カルチノイドクリーゼ
カルチノイドクリーゼとは、生命を脅かすカルチノイド症候群の一種で、極度のストレス、腫瘍の操作（生検または手術）、麻酔によって誘発される腫瘍からの圧倒的な量の生物学的活性化合物の放出に起因するものです。
アナフィラキシーショック
アナフィラキシーショックは、稀にしか起こらないが、すぐに治療しないと命にかかわるような重篤なアレルギー反応です。多くの場合、食物、虫刺され、特定の薬物に対するアレルギーが原因です。エピネフリンと呼ばれる薬剤の注射が早急に必要です。
異常な感染症
原因不明または特異な性質を示す感染症。
感染症の頻発
感染症の頻発とは、感染症の感染数が多すぎたり、重症化したり、長く続いたりすることを指します。頻繁な感染症や再発性の感染症は、体が免疫システムを正常に働かせるために十分な白血球を生産していないために起こる可能性があります。
リンパ球増加
リンパ球増加は、白血球の一種であるリンパ球が体内で通常より多く見受けられることをいいます。リンパ球は免疫システムの一部であり、感染症を撃退するために働きます。
歯肉出血
歯肉出血は、歯周病で最もよく見られる症状です。しかし、それは他の健康問題を指し示すこともあります。歯肉から時々出血するのは、歯を強く磨きすぎていたり、入れ歯が正しく装着されていなかったりすることが原因である可能性があります。また、頻繁に起こる歯茎の出血は、より深刻な問題を示している場合もあります。
T細胞数の増加
T細胞数が多い場合、以下の原因が考えられます：伝染性単核球症（または「キス病」として知られています）、急性リンパ性白血病（ALL）、白血球を侵す癌の一種多発性骨髄腫、骨髄の形質細胞を侵す癌の一種。
赤芽球癆
赤芽球癆（PRCA）または赤芽球減少症は、赤血球の前駆体が影響を受け、白血球が影響を受けないタイプの貧血を指します。PRCAでは、骨髄での赤血球の産生が停止します。PRCAを引き起こす病因は複数存在します。
好中球減少
好中球減少症とは、好中球が少ない状態のことをいいます。好中球は白血球の一種です。すべての白血球は、感染症への抵抗を助けます。好中球は、体内に侵入した有害な細菌や真菌（酵母）を破壊することによって、感染と戦います。好中球は骨髄で作られます。
脾腫
脾腫は、脾臓が肥大することで起こる病気です。一般的には、脾臓肥大、脾臓腫大とも呼ばれます。
Ruptured Spleen
脾臓破裂は、脾臓を覆っているカプセル状のものが破れ、血液がお腹の中に流れ込むことで起こる救急疾患です。破裂の大きさによっては、大量の内出血を起こすことがあります。
肝腫脹
肝腫脹とは、患者さんの肝臓が異常に大きいことをいいます。健康上の重大な問題の兆候であることが多いです。
血小板減少症
血小板減少症は、血小板の数が少ない状態です。血小板（血球細胞）は無色の血液細胞で、血液を凝固させる働きがあります。血小板は、血管の傷の中で固まり栓を形成することで出血を止めます。
PML-RARA 融合遺伝子の発見
APL（急性前骨髄球性白血病）細胞は、15番と17番の染色体の一部が入れ替わる「染色体転座」という非常に特殊な異常があります。その結果、"PML/RARα "として知られる異常な融合遺伝子が形成されます。この変異した遺伝子が、この病気の多くの特徴を引き起こすのです。
FISH検査陽性
患者の病巣を検査し、FISH検査で悪性であることが確認されました。
フィラデルフィア染色体異常の発見
フィラデルフィア染色体またはフィラデルフィア転座（Ph）は、白血病がん細胞（特に慢性骨髄性白血病（CML）細胞）の22番染色体における特定の遺伝子異常です。フィラデルフィア染色体の染色体異常は、9番と22番という2つの染色体の一部が入れ替わる相互転座です。この転座の存在はCMLのほとんどの症例で確認できるため、CMLの高感度検査として用いられます。
ミエロペルオキシダーゼ（MPO）陽性
ミエロペルオキシダーゼは、好中球およびその前駆体である好酸球、単球のアズール顆粒に存在するリソゾーム酵素です。この染色は、主に急性骨髄性白血病と急性リンパ性白血病の鑑別に用いられます。
ズダン染色検査陽性
ソルベントブラック3は、アゾ系色素です。無蛍光で比較的熱に強いリゾクローム（脂溶性染料）ジアゾ染料で、凍結切片の中性トリグリセリドや脂質、パラフィン切片の一部のリポ蛋白の染色に使用されています。実験室では、ズダン染料にソルベントブラック3が使用されます。血液疾患の鑑別には、骨髄芽細胞は染まりますが、リンパ芽細胞は染まりません。
イソクエン酸デヒドロゲナーゼ(IDH1/2)変異の発見

イソクエン酸デヒドロゲナーゼ（IDH）は、トリカルボン酸サイクルにおいてイソクエン酸からα-ケトグルタル酸（α-KG）への変換に関与する重要な酵素であり、この酵素を阻害することにより、TCAサイクルが阻害される。IDHの変異により新型酵素が生成され、R-2-HGの異常蓄積を引き起こし、白血病の発症を促進することがあります。IDH変異は急性骨髄性白血病（AML）患者の20％に認められ、主にIDH1 R132、IDH2 R140、IDH2 R172が含まれています。
BCR-ABL融合遺伝子の発見
BCR-ABLは、BCRとABLと呼ばれる2つの遺伝子が組み合わさってできる変異です。融合遺伝子と呼ばれることもあります。BCR遺伝子は通常22番染色体上にあります。ABL遺伝子は通常9番染色体上にあります。BCR-ABL変異は、BCR遺伝子とABL遺伝子の断片が途切れて場所が入れ替わることで起こります。
トリソミー8遺伝子の発見
トリソミー8は、ワルカニー症候群2としても知られており、8番染色体を3本持つことによって起こるヒトの染色体異常です（トリソミー）。この疾患は、モザイクを伴う場合と伴わない場合があります。モザイク」とは、ある細胞には余分な染色体が存在するが、他の細胞には存在しないことを意味します。
トリソミー9遺伝子の発見
モザイク型トリソミー9は、第9染色体全体が体の一部の細胞で2回ではなく3回出現する（トリソミー）まれな染色体異常です。モザイク」とは、ある細胞には余分な9番染色体が存在し、他の細胞には通常の染色体対が存在することを意味します。
フィラデルフィア染色体重複
欠陥染色体であるフィラデルフィア染色体の重複が検出されました。これは慢性骨髄性白血病のより進行した段階で発生する可能性があります。
軽度な血中芽細胞数の上昇
検査により、患者さんの血液中に高いレベルの芽細胞が検出されました（5～19％）。芽細胞は、好中球、単球、リンパ球、赤血球など、成熟した循環血液細胞の前駆体です。 通常、芽細胞は骨髄に少ない数で存在し、血液中にはそれほど多くは見られません。
血中芽細胞数の上昇
検査により、患者さんの血液中に高濃度の芽細胞が検出されました（20％以上）。芽細胞は、好中球、単球、リンパ球、赤血球など、成熟した循環血液細胞の前駆体です。 通常、芽細胞は骨髄に少ない数で存在し、 血液中にはそれほど多くは見られません。
大幅な血中芽細胞数の上昇
検査により、患者さんの血液中に非常に高いレベルの芽細胞が検出されました（30％以上）。このレベルでは、芽細胞が正常な白血球を押しのけてしまうため、白血球の働きが悪くなってしまいます。芽細胞は、好中球、単球、リンパ球、赤血球など、成熟した循環血液細胞の前駆体です。 通常、芽細胞は骨髄に少ない数で存在し、 血液中にはそれほど多くは見られません。
Neprilysin (CD10) Bright Expression

Neprilysin, also known as membrane metallo-endopeptidase, neutral endopeptidase, cluster of differentiation 10, and common acute lymphoblastic leukemia antigen is an enzyme that in humans is encoded by the MME gene. Identified in common acute lymphoblastic leukemia as a cancer specific antigen, CD10 is a cell surface ectoenzyme widely expressed on different types of cells.
Neprilysin (CD10) Negative Expression

Neprilysin, also known as membrane metallo-endopeptidase, neutral endopeptidase, cluster of differentiation 10, and common acute lymphoblastic leukemia antigen is an enzyme that in humans is encoded by the MME gene. Identified in common acute lymphoblastic leukemia as a cancer specific antigen, CD10 is a cell surface ectoenzyme widely expressed on different types of cells.
CD19 Antigen Bright Expression

B-lymphocyte antigen CD19, also known as CD19 molecule, B-Lymphocyte Surface Antigen B4, T-Cell Surface Antigen Leu-12 and CVID3 is a transmembrane protein that in humans is encoded by the gene CD19. In humans, CD19 is expressed in all B lineage cells, except for plasma cells, and in follicular dendritic cells.
CD19 Antigen Negative Expression

B-lymphocyte antigen CD19, also known as CD19 molecule, B-Lymphocyte Surface Antigen B4, T-Cell Surface Antigen Leu-12 and CVID3 is a transmembrane protein that in humans is encoded by the gene CD19. In humans, CD19 is expressed in all B lineage cells, except for plasma cells, and in follicular dendritic cells.
CD20 Antigen Dim Expression

B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 or CD20 is expressed on the surface of all B-cells beginning at the pro-B phase and progressively increasing in concentration until maturity. CD20 is a membrane-embedded surface molecule which plays a role in the development and differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells.
CD20 Antigen Bright Expression

B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 or CD20 is expressed on the surface of all B-cells beginning at the pro-B phase and progressively increasing in concentration until maturity. CD20 is a membrane-embedded surface molecule which plays a role in the development and differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells.
TdT Antigen Bright Expression

Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT), also known as DNA nucleotidylexotransferase (DNTT) or terminal transferase, is a specialized DNA polymerase expressed in immature, pre-B, pre-T lymphoid cells, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma cells.
TdT Antigen Negative Expression

Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT), also known as DNA nucleotidylexotransferase (DNTT) or terminal transferase, is a specialized DNA polymerase expressed in immature, pre-B, pre-T lymphoid cells, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma cells.
CD22 Antigen Dim Expression

CD22, or cluster of differentiation-22, is a molecule belonging to the SIGLEC family of lectins. It is found on the surface of mature B cells and to a lesser extent on some immature B cells. CD22 is a sugar binding transmembrane protein, which specifically binds sialic acid with an immunoglobulin (Ig) domain located at its N-terminus. The presence of Ig domains makes CD22 a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. CD22 functions as an inhibitory receptor for B cell receptor (BCR) signaling.
CD22 Antigen Bright Expression

CD22, or cluster of differentiation-22, is a molecule belonging to the SIGLEC family of lectins. It is found on the surface of mature B cells and to a lesser extent on some immature B cells. CD22 is a sugar binding transmembrane protein, which specifically binds sialic acid with an immunoglobulin (Ig) domain located at its N-terminus. The presence of Ig domains makes CD22 a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. CD22 functions as an inhibitory receptor for B cell receptor (BCR) signaling.
Fc epsilon RII (CD23) Bright Expression

CD23, also known as Fc epsilon RII, or FcεRII, is the "low-affinity" receptor for IgE, an antibody isotype involved in allergy and resistance to parasites, and is important in regulation of IgE levels. Unlike many of the antibody receptors, CD23 is a C-type lectin. CD23 antigen is a cell surface protein considered important in the differentiation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
CD34 Antigen Bright Expression

The CD34 protein is a member of a family of single-pass transmembrane sialomucin proteins that show expression on early hematopoietic and vascular-associated tissue. CD34 is also an important adhesion molecule and is required for T cells to enter lymph nodes. It is expressed on lymph node endothelia, whereas the L-selectin to which it binds is on the T cell.
CD79a Antigen Bright Expression

Cluster of differentiation CD79A also known as B-cell antigen receptor complex-associated protein alpha chain and MB-1 membrane glycoprotein, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CD79A gene. CD79a plays multiple and diverse roles in B cell development and function. The CD79a/b heterodimer associates non-covalently with the immunoglobulin heavy chain through its transmembrane region, thus forming the BCR along with the immunoglobulin light chain and the pre-BCR when associated with the surrogate light chain in developing B cells.
CD79b Antigen Negative Expression

CD79b molecule, immunoglobulin-associated beta, also known as CD79B (Cluster of Differentiation 79B), is a human gene. The CD79a/b heterodimer associates non-covalently with the immunoglobulin heavy chain through its transmembrane region, thus forming the BCR along with the immunoglobulin light chain and the pre-BCR when associated with the surrogate light chain in developing B cells.
Integrin alpha X (CD11c) Bright Expression

CD11c, also known as Integrin, alpha X (complement component 3 receptor 4 subunit) (ITGAX), is a gene that encodes for CD11c. CD11c is a type I transmembrane protein that is expressed on monocytes, granulocytes, a subset of B cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages and may be demonstrated on B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia, marginal zone lymphomas, and hairy cell leukemia.
IL2RA (CD25) Bright Expression

Interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain (also called CD25) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the IL2RA gene. The interleukin 2 (IL2) receptor alpha (IL2RA) and beta (IL2RB) chains, together with the common gamma chain (IL2RG), constitute the high-affinity IL2 receptor. IL2RA is expressed in most B-cell neoplasms, some acute nonlymphocytic leukemias, neuroblastomas, mastocytosis and tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. It functions as the receptor for HTLV-1 and is consequently expressed on neoplastic cells in adult T cell lymphoma/leukemia.
IL2RA (CD25) Negative Expression

Interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain (also called CD25) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the IL2RA gene. The interleukin 2 (IL2) receptor alpha (IL2RA) and beta (IL2RB) chains, together with the common gamma chain (IL2RG), constitute the high-affinity IL2 receptor. IL2RA is expressed in most B-cell neoplasms, some acute nonlymphocytic leukemias, neuroblastomas, mastocytosis and tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. It functions as the receptor for HTLV-1 and is consequently expressed on neoplastic cells in adult T cell lymphoma/leukemia.
ITGAE (CD103) Bright Expression

Integrin, alpha E also known as CD103 is an integrin protein that in human is encoded by the ITGAE gene. CD103 is expressed widely on intraepithelial lymphocyte (IEL) T cells (both αβ T cells and γδ T cells) and on some peripheral regulatory T cells (Tregs). It is useful in identifying hairy cell leukemia which is positive for this marker in contrast to most other hematologic malignancies which are negative for CD103 except enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma.
Interleukin-3 Receptor (CD123) Dim Expression

The interleukin-3 receptor (CD123) is a molecule found on cells which helps transmit the signal of interleukin-3, a soluble cytokine important in the immune system. The receptor, found on pluripotent progenitor cells, induces tyrosine phosphorylation within the cell and promotes proliferation and differentiation within the hematopoietic cell lines. CD123 is expressed across acute myeloid leukemia (AML) subtypes, including leukemic stem cells.
Interleukin-3 Receptor (CD123) Bright Expression

The interleukin-3 receptor (CD123) is a molecule found on cells which helps transmit the signal of interleukin-3, a soluble cytokine important in the immune system. The receptor, found on pluripotent progenitor cells, induces tyrosine phosphorylation within the cell and promotes proliferation and differentiation within the hematopoietic cell lines. CD123 is expressed across acute myeloid leukemia (AML) subtypes, including leukemic stem cells.
Interleukin-3 Receptor (CD123) Negative Expression

The interleukin-3 receptor (CD123) is a molecule found on cells which helps transmit the signal of interleukin-3, a soluble cytokine important in the immune system. The receptor, found on pluripotent progenitor cells, induces tyrosine phosphorylation within the cell and promotes proliferation and differentiation within the hematopoietic cell lines. CD123 is expressed across acute myeloid leukemia (AML) subtypes, including leukemic stem cells.
CD1a Antigen Bright Expression

CD1a (Cluster of Differentiation 1a) is a human protein encoded by the CD1A gene. This gene encodes a member of the CD1 family of transmembrane glycoproteins, which are structurally related to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and form heterodimers with beta-2-microglobulin. The CD1 proteins mediate the presentation of primarily lipid and glycolipid antigens of self or microbial origin to T cells.
CD1a Antigen Negative Expression

CD1a (Cluster of Differentiation 1a) is a human protein encoded by the CD1A gene. This gene encodes a member of the CD1 family of transmembrane glycoproteins, which are structurally related to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins and form heterodimers with beta-2-microglobulin. The CD1 proteins mediate the presentation of primarily lipid and glycolipid antigens of self or microbial origin to T cells.
CD5 Antigen Bright Expression

CD5 is a cluster of differentiation expressed on the surface of T cells (various species) and in a subset of murine B cells known as B-1a. The expression of this receptor in human B cells has been a controversial topic and up to date there is no consensus regarding the role of this receptor as a marker of human B cells. CD5 is a good immunohistochemical marker for T-cells, although not as sensitive as CD3. About 76% of T-cell neoplasms are reported to express CD5, and it is also found in chronic lymphocytic leukemia and mantle cell lymphoma (both being B cell malignancies), that do not express CD3. It is commonly lost in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and its absence can be used as an indicator of malignancy in this condition.
CD7 Antigen Bright Expression

CD7 (Cluster of Differentiation 7) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CD7 gene. This gene encodes a transmembrane protein which is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. This protein is found on thymocytes and mature T cells. It plays an essential role in T-cell interactions and also in T-cell/B-cell interaction during early lymphoid development. This gene encodes a transmembrane protein which is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. This protein is found on thymocytes and mature T cells. It plays an essential role in T-cell interactions and also in T-cell/B-cell interaction during early lymphoid development.
Aminopeptidase N (CD13) Bright Expression

Membrane alanyl aminopeptidase (EC 3.4.11.2) also known as alanyl aminopeptidase (AAP) or aminopeptidase N (AP-N) is an enzyme that in humans is encoded by the ANPEP gene. Aminopeptidase N is located in the small-intestinal and renal microvillar membrane, and also in other plasma membranes. In the small intestine aminopeptidase N plays a role in the final digestion of peptides generated from hydrolysis of proteins by gastric and pancreatic proteases. Its function in proximal tubular epithelial cells and other cell types is less clear. Defects in this gene appear to be a cause of various types of leukemia or lymphoma.
Sialyl-Lewis X (CD15) Bright Expression

Sialyl LewisX (sLeX) also known as cluster of differentiation 15s (CD15s) or stage-specific embryonic antigen 1 (SSEA-1), is a tetrasaccharide carbohydrate which is usually attached to O-glycans on the surface of cells. It is known to play a vital role in cell-to-cell recognition processes. It is also the means by which an egg attracts sperm; first, to stick to it, then bond with it and eventually form a zygote. Sialyl-Lewisx mediates phagocytosis and chemotaxis, found on neutrophils; expressed in patients with Hodgkin disease, some B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and most acute nonlymphocytic leukemias. CD15 is present on almost all Reed–Sternberg cells, including their rare mononuclear variants, and, as such, can be used in immunohistochemistry to identify the presence of such cells in biopsies.
Siglec-3 (CD33) Bright Expression

CD33 or Siglec-3 (sialic acid binding Ig-like lectin 3, SIGLEC3, SIGLEC-3, gp67, p67) is a transmembrane receptor expressed on cells of myeloid lineage. It is usually considered myeloid-specific, but it can also be found on some lymphoid cells. CD33 can be stimulated by any molecule with sialic acid residues such as glycoproteins or glycolipids. Upon binding, the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based inhibition motif (ITIM) of CD33, present on the cytosolic portion of the protein, is phosphorylated and acts as a docking site for Src homology 2 (SH2) domain-containing proteins like SHP phosphatases. This results in a cascade that inhibits phagocytosis in the cell.
Proto-O c-KIT (CD117) Bright Expression

Proto-oncogene c-KIT, also known as tyrosine-protein kinase KIT, CD117 or mast/stem cell growth factor receptor, is a receptor tyrosine kinase protein that in humans is encoded by the KIT gene. KIT is an important cell surface marker used to identify certain types of hematopoietic (blood) progenitors in the bone marrow. To be specific, hematopoietic stem cells (HSC), multipotent progenitors (MPP), and common myeloid progenitors (CMP) express high levels of KIT. Common lymphoid progenitors (CLP) express low surface levels of KIT. Antibodies to KIT are widely used in immunohistochemistry to help distinguish particular types of tumour in histological tissue sections. It is used primarily in the diagnosis of GISTs, which are positive for KIT, but negative for markers such as desmin and S-100, which are positive in smooth muscle and neural tumours, which have a similar appearance.
Proto-O c-KIT (CD117) Negative Expression

Proto-oncogene c-KIT, also known as tyrosine-protein kinase KIT, CD117 or mast/stem cell growth factor receptor, is a receptor tyrosine kinase protein that in humans is encoded by the KIT gene. KIT is an important cell surface marker used to identify certain types of hematopoietic (blood) progenitors in the bone marrow. To be specific, hematopoietic stem cells (HSC), multipotent progenitors (MPP), and common myeloid progenitors (CMP) express high levels of KIT. Common lymphoid progenitors (CLP) express low surface levels of KIT. Antibodies to KIT are widely used in immunohistochemistry to help distinguish particular types of tumour in histological tissue sections. It is used primarily in the diagnosis of GISTs, which are positive for KIT, but negative for markers such as desmin and S-100, which are positive in smooth muscle and neural tumours, which have a similar appearance.
Cyclic ADP RH (CD38) Bright Expression

CD38, also known as cyclic ADP ribose hydrolase is a glycoprotein found on the surface of many immune cells, including CD4⁺, CD8⁺, B lymphocytes and natural killer cells. CD38 also functions in cell adhesion, signal transduction and calcium signaling. The loss of CD38 function is associated with impaired immune responses, metabolic disturbances, and behavioral modifications including social amnesia. The CD38 protein is a marker of cell activation. It has been connected to HIV infection, leukemias, myelomas, solid tumours, type II diabetes mellitus and bone metabolism, as well as some genetically determined conditions.
Cyclic ADP RH (CD38) Dim Expression

CD38, also known as cyclic ADP ribose hydrolase is a glycoprotein found on the surface of many immune cells, including CD4⁺, CD8⁺, B lymphocytes and natural killer cells. CD38 also functions in cell adhesion, signal transduction and calcium signaling. The loss of CD38 function is associated with impaired immune responses, metabolic disturbances, and behavioral modifications including social amnesia. The CD38 protein is a marker of cell activation. It has been connected to HIV infection, leukemias, myelomas, solid tumours, type II diabetes mellitus and bone metabolism, as well as some genetically determined conditions.
Leukosialin (CD43) Bright Expression

Leukosialin also known as sialophorin or CD43 (cluster of differentiation 43) is a transmembrane cell surface protein that in humans is encoded by the SPN (sialophorin) gene. Defects in the CD43 molecule are associated with the development of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Using immunohistochemistry, CD43 can be demonstrated in the paracortical T-cells of healthy lymph nodes and tonsils; it is also positive in a range of lymphoid and myeloid tumours. Although it is present in over 90% of T-cell lymphomas, it is generally less effective at demonstrating this condition than is CD3 antigen. However, it may be useful as part of a panel to demonstrate B-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma, since the malignant cells in this condition are often CD43 positive, and may be difficult to stain with other antibodies.
CD8 Antigen Bright Expression

CD8 (cluster of differentiation 8) is a transmembrane glycoprotein that serves as a co-receptor for the T cell receptor (TCR). Like the TCR, CD8 binds to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule, but is specific for the class I MHC protein. The CD8 co-receptor is predominantly expressed on the surface of cytotoxic T cells, but can also be found on natural killer cells, cortical thymocytes, and dendritic cells. The CD8 molecule is a marker for cytotoxic T cell population. It is expressed in T cell lymphoblastic lymphoma and hypo-pigmented mycosis fungoides.
CD3 Antigen Bright Expression

In immunology, the CD3 (cluster of differentiation 3) T cell co-receptor helps to activate both the cytotoxic T cell (CD8+ naive T cells) and also T helper cells (CD4+ naive T cells). CD3 is initially expressed in the cytoplasm of pro-thymocytes, the stem cells from which T-cells arise in the thymus. The pro-thymocytes differentiate into common thymocytes, and then into medullary thymocytes, and it is at this latter stage that CD3 antigen begins to migrate to the cell membrane. The antigen is found bound to the membranes of all mature T-cells, and in virtually no other cell type, although it does appear to be present in small amounts in Purkinje cells. This high specificity, combined with the presence of CD3 at all stages of T-cell development, makes it a useful immunohistochemical marker for T-cells in tissue sections. The antigen remains present in almost all T-cell lymphomas and leukaemias, and can therefore be used to distinguish them from superficially similar B-cell and myeloid neoplasms.
CD3 Antigen Negative Expression

In immunology, the CD3 (cluster of differentiation 3) T cell co-receptor helps to activate both the cytotoxic T cell (CD8+ naive T cells) and also T helper cells (CD4+ naive T cells). CD3 is initially expressed in the cytoplasm of pro-thymocytes, the stem cells from which T-cells arise in the thymus. The pro-thymocytes differentiate into common thymocytes, and then into medullary thymocytes, and it is at this latter stage that CD3 antigen begins to migrate to the cell membrane. The antigen is found bound to the membranes of all mature T-cells, and in virtually no other cell type, although it does appear to be present in small amounts in Purkinje cells. This high specificity, combined with the presence of CD3 at all stages of T-cell development, makes it a useful immunohistochemical marker for T-cells in tissue sections. The antigen remains present in almost all T-cell lymphomas and leukaemias, and can therefore be used to distinguish them from superficially similar B-cell and myeloid neoplasms.
FcγRIII (CD16) Bright Expression

CD16, also known as FcγRIII, is a cluster of differentiation molecule found on the surface of natural killer cells, neutrophils, monocytes, and macrophages. CD16 has been identified as Fc receptors FcγRIIIa and FcγRIIIb, which participate in signal transduction. These receptors bind to the Fc portion of IgG antibodies, which then activates antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) in human NK cells. CD16 is required for ADCC processes carried out by human monocytes. In humans, monocytes expressing CD16 have a variety of ADCC capabilities in the presence of specific antibodies, and can kill primary leukemic cells, cancer cell lines, and cells infected with hepatitis B virus. In addition, CD16 is able to mediate the direct killing of some virally infected and cancer cells without antibodies.
NC Adhesion Molecule (CD56) Bright Expression

Neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), also called CD56, is a homophilic binding glycoprotein expressed on the surface of neurons, glia and skeletal muscle. Although CD56 is often considered a marker of neural lineage commitment due to its discovery site, CD56 expression is also found in, among others, the hematopoietic system. Here, the expression of CD56 is most stringently associated with, but certainly not limited to, natural killer cells. In anatomic pathology, pathologists make use of CD56 immunohistochemistry to recognize certain tumours. tumours that are CD56-positive are myeloma, myeloid leukemia, neuroendocrine tumours, Wilms' tumour, neuroblastoma, extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type, pancreatic acinar cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, paraganglioma, small cell lung carcinoma, and the Ewing's sarcoma family of tumours.
HLA-DR Bright Expression

HLA-DR is an MHC class II cell surface receptor encoded by the human leukocyte antigen complex on chromosome 6 region 6p21.31. The complex of HLA-DR and peptide, generally between 9 and 30 amino acids in length, constitutes a ligand for the T-cell receptor.
Pancytopenia

Pancytopenia is a condition that occurs when a person has low counts for all three types of blood cells: red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Pancytopenia is usually due to a problem with the bone marrow that produces the blood cells. However, there can be several different underlying causes.
Hairy Looking Cell
Hairy cells are abnormal white blood cells with hair-like projections of cytoplasm. They are a staple sign of Hairy cell leukemia.
TRAP Enzyme Detected

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP or TRAPase), also called acid phosphatase 5, tartrate resistant (ACP5), is a glycosylated monomeric metalloprotein enzyme expressed in mammals. It has a molecular weight of approximately 35kDa, a basic isoelectric point (7.6–9.5), and optimal activity in acidic conditions.
BRAF V600E Mutation Detected

The B-Raf proto-oncogene (BRAF) encodes a cytoplasmic serine/threonine kinase with a key role in regulating the mitogen-activated protein kinase signal transduction pathway. An activating missense mutation in codon 600 of exon 15 (V600E) of BRAF gene has been identified in multiple neoplasms including melanoma, colorectal carcinoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma, hairy cell leukemia, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
IGHV Hypermutation Detected

Ig heavy chain V-III region VH26 is a protein that in humans is encoded by the IGHV@ gene. IGHV is the immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region genes; in B-cell neoplasms like chronic lymphocytic leukemia, mutations of IGHV are associated with better responses to some treatments and with prolonged survival. Approximately 80 to 90 percent of HCL patients have a hypermutation in immunoglobulin heavy chain variable gene.
Deletion Chromosome 17p13 Detected
Testing has detected Chromosome 17p13 is deleted from the patient's tested cells.
Necrosis
Necrosis is a form of cell injury which results in the premature death of cells in living tissue by autolysis.
Large Primary Tumour Detected
Testing has detected a Large Primary Tumour within the patient, this can sometimes be sign that the cancer is in a more advanced state.
Breast Lump
A breast lump is a localized swelling, protuberance, bulge, or bump in the breast that feels different from the breast tissue around it.
Breast Discharge
Nipple discharge is the release of fluid from the nipple. It is a very common breast symptom and in most cases is part of the normal function of the breast rather than being caused by a problem.
Sore Nipple

Nipple pain is pain that occurs in the breast tissue around the area of the nipple. Nipple pain can be associated with other symptoms and signs that may include breast pain, nipple discharge, breast lump or mass, itching, or skin changes. Breast cancer typically does not cause nipple pain or breast pain.
Breast Shape Changes
The patient has experienced a change in the shape or size of their breasts.
Breast Dimpling
Also known as peau d'orange, dimpling of the breast causes the skin to look like the pitting and uneven skin of an orange. Sometimes, the skin can also be red and inflamed.
Breast Pain
Tightness, tenderness or sharp pain in one or both breasts that occurs commonly and usually doesn't mean anything is seriously wrong.
Suspicious Calcifications

Breast calcifications are small calcium deposits that develop in a woman's breast tissue. They are very common and are usually benign (noncancerous). Breast calcifications are more common in women, but can also be found in men. In some instances, certain types of breast calcifications may suggest early breast cancer.
Irregular Breast Density

A potential abnormality on a mammogram might be called a nodule, mass, lump, density, or distortion. A mass (lump) that has an irregular border or a starburst appearance (spiculated) might be cancerous.
Cancer Antigen 15-3 High Blood Levels

Cancer antigen 15-3 (CA15-3) is a protein made by a variety of cells, particularly breast cancer cells. The protein moves into the blood, where it can be measured. CA15-3 levels are higher than normal in most women with breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body (called metastatic breast cancer). Not all types of breast cancer will cause CA 15-3 levels to rise, as some types of cancer cells don’t over-produce the antigen.
Cancer Antigen 27-29 High Blood Levels

Cancer Antigen 27-29 is one of several antigens that doctors use as tumour markers for breast cancer. These markers tend to increase whenever cancer is present. The CA 27.29 test is primarily used to monitor metastatic breast cancer and less commonly to detect recurrence in people previously treated for early-stage breast cancer.
BRCA1 Faulty Gene Findings

BRCA1/2 is a human tumour suppressor gene (also known as a caretaker gene) and is responsible for repairing DNA. BRCA1 and BRCA2 are unrelated proteins, but both are normally expressed in the cells of breast and other tissue, where they help repair damaged DNA, or destroy cells if DNA cannot be repaired. Women who carry a fault in BRCA1 or BRCA2 have a high lifetime risk of breast cancer, estimated to be in the range of 30-60%, and a lifetime ovarian cancer risk of about 20%. They can benefit from measures for prevention and early detection of cancers. Men who carry a fault in BRCA1 or BRCA2 may be at some increased risk of prostate cancer and male breast cancer.
Estrogen Receptor Positive

A cancer is called estrogen-receptor-positive (or ER+) if it has receptors for estrogen. This suggests that the cancer cells, like normal breast cells, may receive signals from estrogen that could promote their growth.
Progesterone Receptor Positive
The cancer is progesterone-receptor-positive (PR+) if it has progesterone receptors. Again, this means that the cancer cells may receive signals from progesterone that could promote their growth.
HER2/neu (CD340) Negative Expression

Receptor tyrosine-protein kinase erbB-2, also known as CD340, proto-oncogene Neu, Erbb2, or ERBB2, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the ERBB2 gene. ERBB is abbreviated from erythroblastic oncogene B, a gene isolated from avian genome. It is also frequently called HER2 or HER2/neu. HER2 is a member of the human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER/EGFR/ERBB) family. Amplification or over-expression of this oncogene has been shown to play an important role in the development and progression of certain aggressive types of breast cancer. In recent years the protein has become an important biomarker and target of therapy for approximately 30% of breast cancer patients.
HER2/neu (CD340) Positive Mutation

Receptor tyrosine-protein kinase erbB-2, also known as CD340, proto-oncogene Neu, Erbb2, or ERBB2, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the ERBB2 gene. ERBB is abbreviated from erythroblastic oncogene B, a gene isolated from avian genome. It is also frequently called HER2 or HER2/neu. HER2 is a member of the human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER/EGFR/ERBB) family. Amplification or over-expression of this oncogene has been shown to play an important role in the development and progression of certain aggressive types of breast cancer. In recent years the protein has become an important biomarker and target of therapy for approximately 30% of breast cancer patients.
Spiculated Margins
Spiculated margins are a true diagnostic feature of malignancy. Strands of tissue are seen radiating out from an ill-defined mass, producing a stellate appearance.
CD44v6 Antigen Bright Expression

CD44v6 is an isoform of the CD44 family of transmembrane glycoproteins. High CD44v6 expression in epithelial cancer correlates with tumour growth, invasion, metastasis, and recurrence. CD44v6 is a co-receptor of the receptor tyrosine kinases c-Met, RON and VEGFR-2.
GATA3 Mutation Findings

GATA3 is a transcription factor that in humans is encoded by the GATA3 gene. The GATA3 transcription factor is critical for the embryonic development of various tissues as well as for inflammatory and humoral immune responses and the proper functioning of the endothelium of blood vessels. Immuocytochemical analysis of GATA3 protein in breast cells is a valuable marker for diagnosing primary breast cancer, being tested as positive in up to 94% of cases.
Severe Hemoptysis

Hemoptysis is the coughing up of blood or blood-stained mucus from the bronchi, larynx, trachea, or lungs. In other words, it is the airway bleeding. This can occur with lung cancer, infections such as tuberculosis, bronchitis, or pneumonia, and certain cardiovascular conditions.
Increased Intracranial Pressure

Increased intracranial pressure (ICP) is a rise in pressure around your brain. It may be due to an increase in the amount of fluid surrounding your brain. For example, there may be an increased amount of the cerebrospinal fluid that naturally cushions your brain or an increase in blood in the brain due to an injury or a ruptured tumour.
Abnormal Brain Wave Patterns

EEG has detected abnormal brain wave patterns. Spikes, sharp waves, or spike-wave complexes occurring with consistent localization are observed sometimes early in the course of brain tumours. However, they are more common either as early findings of slowly growing neoplasms associated with seizures or later after focal slowing has developed.
Abnormal Mass Detected
Testing has detected an abnormal mass within the patient, further testing is required to identify malignancy, type or progression.
Neurofibromatosis Type I (NF-1) Findings

Neurofibromatosis type I (NF-1) is a complex multi-system human disorder caused by the mutation of a gene on chromosome 17 that is responsible for production of a protein called neurofibromin which is needed for normal function in many human cell types. Approximately 10% of patients with neurofibromatosis I (NFI) patients will have central nervous system (CNS) tumours. The most common of these are hypothalamic-optic gliomas, followed by brainstem and cerebellar pilocytic astrocytomas.
Eosinophilic Granular Bodies

The frequent presence of eosinophilic granular bodies is often a useful clue in deterring a higher grade neoplasm toward a lower grade tumour, such as a pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma (PXA) or a pilocytic astrocytoma.
Abscess
Focal Neurologic Deficit

A focal neurologic deficit is a problem with nerve, spinal cord, or brain function. It affects a specific location, such as the left side of the face, right arm, or even a small area such as the tongue. Speech, vision, and hearing problems are also considered focal neurological deficits.
Calcified Mineral Deposits

Brain stones or cerebral calculi are defined as large solid intracranial calcifications. While considered by many to be benign, these calcium phosphate deposits or "brain stones" can become large and are associated with neurological symptoms that range from seizures to parkinsonian symptoms. Dystrophic calcifications are most commonly seen in areas of brain injury such as trauma, surgery, stroke and radiation treatment.
Dysphasia
Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (LFS)
Li-Fraumeni syndrome (LFS) is an inherited familial predisposition to a wide range of certain, often rare, cancers. This is due to a change (mutation) in a tumour suppressor gene known as TP53.
Dysphasia is a language disorder marked by deficiency in the generation of speech, and sometimes also in its comprehension, due to brain disease or damage.
Microcysts
A microcyst is simply a very small cyst. Cysts are an abnormal, usually noncancerous growth filled with liquid or a semisolid substance, sometimes causing pain.
Antigen KI-67 Low Labeling Index

Antigen KI-67 also known as Ki-67 or MKI67 is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MKI67 gene (antigen identified by monoclonal antibody Ki-67). Ki-67 is an excellent marker to determine the growth fraction of a given cell population. The fraction of Ki-67-positive tumour cells (the Ki-67 labeling index) is often correlated with the clinical course of cancer.
Antigen KI-67 Brisk Labeling Index
Loss of Heterozygosity

Loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arm 10q is the most frequent gene alteration for both primary and secondary glioblastomas; it occurs in 60-90% of cases. This mutation appears to be specific for glioblastoma multiforme and is found rarely in other tumour grades. This mutation is associated with poor survival. LOH at 10q plus 1 or 2 of the additional gene mutations appear to be frequent alterations and are most likely major players in the development of glioblastomas.
Overexpression of PDGFR

Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) is one among numerous growth factors that regulate cell growth and division. In particular, PDGF plays a significant role in blood vessel formation, the growth of blood vessels from already-existing blood vessel tissue, mitogenesis, i.e. proliferation, of mesenchymal cells. In Oncology, the PDGF gene acts as a major mitogen for glial cells by binding to the PDGF receptor (PDGFR). Amplification or overexpression of PDGFR is typical in the pathway leading to secondary glioblastomas.
IDH1/IDH2 Mutation Negative
Dyspareunia (Female)

Painful intercourse can occur for reasons that range from structural problems to psychological concerns. Many women have painful intercourse at some point in their lives. The medical term for painful intercourse is dyspareunia, defined as persistent or recurrent genital pain that occurs just before, during or after intercourse.
Cancer Antigen 125 High Blood Levels

CA-125 also known as mucin 16 or MUC16 is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MUC16 gene. MUC16 is a member of the mucin family glycoproteins. A CA 125 test measures the amount of the protein CA 125 (cancer antigen 125) in your blood. A CA 125 test may be used to monitor certain cancers during and after treatment. In some cases, a CA 125 test may be used to look for early signs of ovarian cancer in people with a very high risk of the disease. The amount of CA-125 is higher with ovarian cancer. In premenopausal women, many other illnesses or diseases besides cancer can cause higher levels of CA-125.
Early Satiety
Early satiety is the inability to eat a full meal or feeling full after only a small amount of food.
Postmenopausal Bleeding

Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is defined as bleeding that occurs after 1 year of amenorrhea in a woman who is not receiving hormone therapy (HT). Women on continuous progesterone and oestrogen hormone therapy can expect to have irregular vaginal bleeding, especially for the first 6 months. There can be several causes of postmenopausal bleeding. The most common causes are: inflammation and thinning of the vaginal lining (atrophic vaginitis) or womb lining (endometrial atrophy) – caused by lower oestrogen levels.
Irregular Menstruation

Missed, delayed or erratic periods or abnormal bleeding patterns. Irregular menstruation can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include family history of irregular menstruation, menopause or menarche, physical stress, psychological stress, smoking or medication side effects.
Abnormal Pelvic Mass Detected

A pelvic mass is an enlargement or swelling in the pelvic region. Most pelvic masses are discovered during routine gynaecologic or physical examinations. Pelvic masses may originate from either the gynaecologic organs, such as the cervix, uterus, uterine adnexa, or from other pelvic organs, such as the intestines, bladder, ureters, and renal organs. There are many gynecologic problems that can result in a pelvic mass. Additionally, there are other diseases that may also result in a pelvic mass. Most are benign conditions, such as an Ovarian Cyst, while others can be related to gynecologic cancer.
Ovarian Cysts

Ovarian cysts are fluid-filled sacs or pockets in an ovary or on its surface. Most ovarian cysts don't cause symptoms. In some cases, menstrual irregularities, pain during intercourse or irregular bowel movements can occur. Most ovarian cysts are harmless and often clear up on their own without treatment.
Micropapillary Invasion Pattern

A micropapillary pattern is defined as a pattern showing micropapillary structures without a fibrovascular core. It is well known that the presence of a micropapillary pattern leads to a poorer prognosis in ovary, breast and bladder cancer.
Psammoma Body

Psammoma bodies are round microscopic calcific collections. Psammoma bodies are a common finding in well-differentiated serous carcinoma and they may be found in association with malignant glandular cells detected with cervicovaginal cytology.
BRAF V599E Mutation Detected

The B-Raf proto-oncogene (BRAF) encodes a cytoplasmic serine/threonine kinase with a key role in regulating the mitogen-activated protein kinase signal transduction pathway. Mutations in the BRAF-gene are found in benign and malignant melanocytic lesions, >90% being a V599E mutation. This mutation results in constitutively active kinase function and increased colony formation in vitro.
Ascites
Abdominal swelling caused by accumulation of fluid, most often related to liver disease.
Pleural Effusion

Pleural effusion, sometimes referred to as “water on the lungs,” is the build-up of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs. The pleura are thin membranes that line the lungs and the inside of the chest cavity and act to lubricate and facilitate breathing.
MCAM (CD146) Bright Expression
Melanoma cell adhesion molecule (MCAM) is a cell adhesion molecule that is abnormally expressed in a variety of tumours and is closely associated with tumour metastasis.
Keratin 7 (CK7) Bright Expression

Keratin, type II cytoskeletal 7 also known as cytokeratin-7 (CK-7) or keratin-7 (K7) or sarcolectin (SCL) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the KRT7 gene. Keratin-7 is found in simple glandular epithelia, and in transitional epithelium. Epithelial cells of the lung and breast both contain keratin-7, but some other glandular epithelia, such as those of the colon and prostate, do not. Because the keratin-7 antigen is found in both healthy and neoplastic cells, antibodies to CK7 can be used in immunohistochemistry to distinguish ovarian and transitional cell carcinomas from colonic and prostate cancers, respectively. It is commonly used together with CK20 when making such diagnoses.
Keratin 7 (CK7) Negative Expression

Keratin, type II cytoskeletal 7 also known as cytokeratin-7 (CK-7) or keratin-7 (K7) or sarcolectin (SCL) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the KRT7 gene. Keratin-7 is found in simple glandular epithelia, and in transitional epithelium. Epithelial cells of the lung and breast both contain keratin-7, but some other glandular epithelia, such as those of the colon and prostate, do not. Because the keratin-7 antigen is found in both healthy and neoplastic cells, antibodies to CK7 can be used in immunohistochemistry to distinguish ovarian and transitional cell carcinomas from colonic and prostate cancers, respectively. It is commonly used together with CK20 when making such diagnoses.
Keratin 20 (CK20) Bright Expression

Keratin 20, often abbreviated CK20, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the KRT20 gene. In immunohistochemistry, antibodies to CK20 can be used to identify a range of adenocarcinoma arising from epithelia that normally contain the CK20 protein. For example, the protein is commonly found in colorectal cancer, transitional cell carcinomas and in Merkel cell carcinoma, but is absent in lung cancer, prostate cancer, and non-mucinous ovarian cancer. It is often used in combination with antibodies to CK7 to distinguish different types of glandular tumour.
Keratin 20 (CK20) Negative Expression

Keratin 20, often abbreviated CK20, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the KRT20 gene. In immunohistochemistry, antibodies to CK20 can be used to identify a range of adenocarcinoma arising from epithelia that normally contain the CK20 protein. For example, the protein is commonly found in colorectal cancer, transitional cell carcinomas and in Merkel cell carcinoma, but is absent in lung cancer, prostate cancer, and non-mucinous ovarian cancer. It is often used in combination with antibodies to CK7 to distinguish different types of glandular tumour.
IDH1/IDH2 Negative Findings

Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) is a key enzyme involved in the conversion of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate (α-KG) in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. IDH mutation produces a neomorphic enzyme, which can lead to the abnormal accumulation of R-2-HG and promotes leukemogenesis. IDH mutation occurs in 20% of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients, mainly including IDH1 R132, IDH2 R140, and IDH2 R172.
Prostate Specific Antigen High Levels

Prostate specific antigen (PSA) is a glycoprotein produced solely by the prostate. Its function is to liquefy semen. Small amounts leak into the bloodstream, where it can be measured. Prostate specific antigen is tissue-specific but not cancer-specific. Elevated levels can occur in men with benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH), prostatitis, urinary tract infection or prostatic infarction.
Dysorgasmia
Dysorgasmia is defined as a painful orgasm, but without any prior pain during sexual intercourse. The pain is often a cramping sensation in the pelvis, buttock or abdomen.
Abnormal Prostate Findings
Testing has found abnormalities with the patient's prostate.
Urinary Retention

Difficulty urinating and completely emptying the bladder. Urinary retention can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include holding in urine intentionally or medication side effects.
Frequent Urination at Night

A frequent need to get up and go to the bathroom to urinate at night is called nocturia. It differs from enuresis, or bedwetting, in which the person does not arouse from sleep, but the bladder empties anyway. Nocturia is a common cause of sleep loss, especially among older adults.
Prostate Cancer Antigen 3 High Levels
Prostate cancer antigen 3 (PCA3) is highly expressed in prostatic tumours. Testing has returned high urine levels of PCA3.
Erectile Dysfunction

Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the inability to get or keep an erection firm enough to have sexual intercourse. It's sometimes referred to as impotence, although this term is now used less often. Occasional ED isn't uncommon. Many men experience it during times of stress. Erectile dysfunction following radical prostatectomy for clinically localized prostate cancer is a known potential complication of the surgery.
Hematospermia

Hematospermia is defined as blood in the semen. While often perceived as having little significance, blood in the ejaculate can cause great concern to the men who experience it. The condition is common, with many episodes going unnoticed; therefore, the prevalence of hematospermia remains unknown.
Hypercalcemia

Hypercalcemia is a condition in which the calcium level in your blood is above normal. Hypercalcaemia is most often caused by overactivity in the four tiny glands in the neck (parathyroid glands) or from cancer. Extra calcium in the blood affects many bodily systems.
Severe Hypercalcemia

Severe hypercalcemia is a medical emergency requiring urgent treatment. Hypercalcemia is a condition in which the calcium level in your blood is above normal. Rarely, severe hypercalcemia can interfere with your heart function, causing palpitations and fainting, indications of cardiac arrhythmia, and other heart problems.
Aminopeptidase N (CD13) Negative Expression
CD30 Antigen Bright Expression

CD30, also known as TNFRSF8, is a cell membrane protein of the tumour necrosis factor receptor family and tumour marker. This receptor is expressed by activated, but not by resting, T and B cells. TRAF2 and TRAF5 can interact with this receptor, and mediate the signal transduction that leads to the activation of NF-kappaB. CD30 is associated with anaplastic large cell lymphoma. It is expressed in embryonal carcinoma but not in seminoma and is thus a useful marker in distinguishing between these germ cell tumours. CD30 and CD15 are also expressed on Reed-Sternberg cells typical for Hodgkin's lymphoma.
PTPRC (CD45) Bright Expression

Protein tyrosine phosphatase, receptor type, C also known as PTPRC is an enzyme that, in humans, is encoded by the PTPRC gene. PTPRC is also known as CD45 antigen (CD stands for cluster of differentiation), which was originally called leukocyte common antigen (LCA). CD45 is a pan-leukocyte protein with tyrosine phosphatase activity involved in the regulation of signal transduction in hematopoiesis. CD45 does not colocalize with lipid rafts on murine and human non-transformed hematopoietic cells, but CD45 positioning within lipid rafts is modified during their oncogenic transformation to acute myeloid leukemia.
IGH-BCL2 Translocation
The hallmark of Follicular lymphoma (FL) is the aberrant translocation t(14; 18)(q32; q21) involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and BCL2 gene on chromosome 18.
BCL6 (3q27) Hypermutation

B-cell lymphoma 6 protein is a protein that in humans is encoded by the BCL6 gene. Like BCL2, BCL3, BCL5, BCL7A, BCL9 and BCL10, it has clinical significance in lymphoma. The protein encoded by this gene is an evolutionarily conserved zinc finger transcription factor and contains an N-terminal POZ/BTB domain. This protein acts as a sequence-specific repressor of transcription and has been shown to modulate the STAT-dependent Interleukin 4 (IL-4) responses of B cells. This protein can interact with several corepressor complexes to inhibit transcription. This gene is found to be frequently translocated and hypermutated in diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
BCL2 Bright Expression

Bcl-2 (B-cell lymphoma 2), encoded in humans by the BCL2 gene, is the founding member of the Bcl-2 family of regulator proteins that regulate cell death (apoptosis), by either inhibiting (anti-apoptotic) or inducing (pro-apoptotic) apoptosis. Antibodies to Bcl-2 can be used with immunohistochemistry to identify cells containing the antigen. In healthy tissue, these antibodies react with B-cells in the mantle zone, as well as some T-cells. However, positive cells increase considerably in follicular lymphoma, as well as many other forms of cancer. In some cases, the presence or absence of Bcl-2 staining in biopsies may be significant for the patient's prognosis or likelihood of relapse.
Diffuse Growth Pattern
Vaguely nodular and/or diffuse cellular growth pattern.
Abnormally Coloured Nodule
The patient has a nodule (a lump) on the skin that has a strange red/violet colour.
Merkel Cell Polyomavirus Findings

Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCV or MCPyV) was first described in January 2008 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. It was the first example of a human viral pathogen discovered using unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing with a technique called digital transcriptome subtraction. MCV is one of seven currently known human oncoviruses. Detection of the virus is still at a research phase and is generally not available as a clinical test. Detection of viral DNA is performed by PCR or FISH.
Electron Microscope MCV Findings

Transmission electron microscopy of MCV VLP at ×50,000 magnification shows characteristic polyomaviral icosahedral capsid structures. This evidence points towards Merkel cell polyomavirus or MCV, which is one of seven currently known human oncoviruses.
Cyclin D1 Overproduction

Cyclin D1 is a protein that regulates entry of the cell into cell cycle. It drives the transition between G0 and G1 phase. In normal tissues, basal epithelial cells, endothelial cells, and stromal cells are often cyclin D1 positive, as these cells are going through the cell cycle. As a result of a translocation involving the cyclin D1 gene and IgH, t(11;14), the vast majority of mantle cell lymphomas overexpress cyclin D1. This is a useful feature in the classification of low-grade B-cell lymphomas.
IGH/CCND1 Translocation Findings

IGH gene rearrangements are considered to be one of the classical cytogenetic gene aberrations associated with numerous cancers. The molecular hallmark of MCL, t(11;14)(q13;q32) (IGH/CCND1), results in deregulation and overexpression of the G1-phase cell cycle gene, CCND1 (encoding cyclin D1), mediated by enhancer elements found throughout the IGH locus.
Salt-and-Pepper Chromatin

In pathology, salt-and-pepper chromatin, also salt-and-pepper nuclei and stippled chromatin, refers to cell nuclei that demonstrate granular chromatin (on light microscopy). Salt-and-pepper chromatin is typically seen in endocrine tumours such as medullary thyroid carcinoma, neuroendocrine tumours and pheochromocytoma.
Large Anaplastic Cells

Anaplastic cells display marked pleomorphism (variability). The nuclei are characteristically extremely hyperchromatic (darkly stained) and large. The nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio may approach 1:1 instead of the normal 1:4 or 1:6. Giant cells that are considerably larger than their neighbors may be formed and possess either one enormous nucleus or several nuclei (syncytia). Anaplastic nuclei are variable and bizarre in size and shape.
Thyroid Transcription Factor 1 Positive

NK2 homeobox 1 (NKX2-1), also known as thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1), is a protein which in humans is encoded by the NKX2-1 gene. TTF-1 positive cells are found in the lung as type II pneumocytes and club cells. In the thyroid, follicular and parafollicular cells are also positive for TTF-1. For lung cancers, adenocarcinomas are usually positive, while squamous cell carcinomas and large cell carcinomas are rarely positive. Small cell carcinomas (of any primary site) are usually positive. TTF1 is more than merely a clinical marker of lung adenocarcinoma. It plays an active role in sustaining lung cancer cells in view of the experimental observation that it is mutated in lung cancer.
Tumour Protein P63 Bright Expression

Tumour protein p63, typically referred to as p63, also known as transformation-related protein 63 is a protein that in humans is encoded by the TP63 (also known as the p63) gene. P63 immunostaining has utility for head and neck squamous cell carcinomas, differentiating prostatic adenocarcinoma (the most common type of prostate cancer) and benign prostatic tissue.
Hypertrophic Pulmonary Osteoarthropathy

Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy (HPO) is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome that is frequently associated with lung cancer. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (HOA) is a clinical syndrome of clubbing of the fingers and toes, enlargement of the extremities, and painful, swollen joints. This condition is characterized by symmetric periostitis involving the radius and fibula and, to a lesser extent, the femur, humerus, metacarpals, and metatarsals.
CD44 Antigen Bright Expression

The CD44 antigen is a cell-surface glycoprotein involved in cell–cell interactions, cell adhesion and migration. In humans, the CD44 antigen is encoded by the CD44 gene on Chromosome 11. CD44 is a cell surface adhesion receptor that is highly expressed in many cancers and regulates metastasis via recruitment of CD44 to the cell surface. Its interaction with appropriate extracellular matrix ligands promotes the migration and invasion processes involved in metastases.
EGFR Mutation Over-Expression

The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR; ErbB-1; HER1 in humans) is a transmembrane protein that is a receptor for members of the epidermal growth factor family (EGF family) of extracellular protein ligands. Mutations that lead to EGFR overexpression (known as upregulation or amplification) have been associated with a number of cancers, including adenocarcinoma of the lung (40% of cases), anal cancers, glioblastoma (50%) and epithelian tumours of the head and neck (80-100%). These somatic mutations involving EGFR lead to its constant activation, which produces uncontrolled cell division.
PD-L1 (CD274) Bright Expression

Programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) also known as cluster of differentiation 274 (CD274) or B7 homolog 1 (B7-H1) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CD274 gene. Programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) is a 40kDa type 1 transmembrane protein that has been speculated to play a major role in suppressing the adaptive arm of immune system during particular events such as pregnancy, tissue allografts, autoimmune disease and other disease states such as hepatitis.
Tumour Protein P53 Abnormal Expression

Tumour protein p53, also known as p53, cellular tumour antigen p53 (UniProt name), tumour suppressor p53 is any isoform of a protein encoded by homologous genes in various organisms, such as TP53 (humans) and Trp53 (mice). This homolog (originally thought to be, and often spoken of as, a single protein) is crucial in multicellular organisms, where it prevents cancer formation, and thus functions as a tumour suppressor. The TP53 gene can also be modified by mutagens (chemicals, radiation, or viruses), increasing the likelihood for uncontrolled cell division.
Signet Ring Cell Morphology

In histology, a signet ring cell is a cell with a large vacuole, the malignant type is seen predominantly in carcinomas. Signet ring cells are most frequently associated with various forms of cancer. By definition, a 50% or greater (High) signet-ring-cell component is required for a colorectal carcinoma to be designated as a signet-ring-cell colorectal carcinoma.
High-Degree Microsatellite Instability

Microsatellite instability (MSI) is the condition of genetic hypermutability (predisposition to mutation) that results from impaired DNA mismatch repair (MMR). The presence of MSI represents phenotypic evidence that MMR is not functioning normally. MMR corrects errors that spontaneously occur during DNA replication, such as single base mismatches or short insertions and deletions. The proteins involved in MMR correct polymerase errors by forming a complex that binds to the mismatched section of DNA, excises the error, and inserts the correct sequence in its place. Cells with abnormally functioning MMR are unable to correct errors that occur during DNA replication and consequently accumulate errors. Microsatellite instability is associated with many forms of cancer but is most prevalent in associations with colon cancers.
Mucin 4 Highly Expressed

Mucin 4 (MUC 4) is a mucin protein that in humans is encoded by the MUC4 gene. Like other mucins, MUC-4 is a high-molecular weight glycoprotein. The major constituents of mucus, the viscous secretion that covers epithelial surfaces such as those in the trachea, colon, and cervix, are highly glycosylated proteins called mucins. These glycoproteins play important roles in the protection of the epithelial cells and have been implicated in epithelial renewal and differentiation. MUC-4 has been found to play various roles in the progression of cancer, particularly due to its signaling and anti-adhesive properties which contribute to tumour development and metastasis.
CDH1 (CD324) Mutation Findings

Cadherin-1 also known as CAM 120/80 or epithelial cadherin (E-cadherin) or uvomorulin is a protein that in humans is encoded by the CDH1 gene. CDH1 has also been designated as CD324 (cluster of differentiation 324). It is a tumour suppressor gene. Loss of E-cadherin function or expression has been implicated in cancer progression and metastasis. E-cadherin downregulation decreases the strength of cellular adhesion within a tissue, resulting in an increase in cellular motility. This in turn may allow cancer cells to cross the basement membrane and invade surrounding tissues.
Colonoscopic Findings
Testing has reported unusual colon findings. Further tests or results from the biopsy will help determine if the findings are cause for concern.
Mucin 2 Highly Expressed

Mucins are a family of high molecular weight, heavily glycosylated proteins (glycoconjugates) produced by epithelial tissues in most animals. Mucin 2, oligomeric mucus gel-forming, also known as MUC2, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MUC2 gene. Mucin 2 is particularly prominent in the gut where it is secreted from goblet cells in the epithelial lining into the lumen of the large intestine. In Oncology, overexpression of MUC-2 might protect against antitumour immune effectors by forming a mucous layer, thus promoting tumour development.
Mucin 5AC Highly Expressed

Heavily glycosylated secreted mucin MUC5AC, by the virtue of its cysteine-rich repeats, can form inter- and intramolecular disulfide linkages resulting in complex polymers, which in turn craft the framework of the polymeric mucus gel on epithelial cell surfaces. MUC5AC is a molecule with versatile functional implications including barrier functions to epithelial cells, host–pathogen interaction, immune cell attraction to sites of premalignant or malignant lesions and tumor progression in a context-dependent manner. Differential expression, glycosylation and localization of MUC5AC have been associated with a plethora of benign and malignant pathologies.
Mucin 1 Highly Expressed

Mucin 1, cell surface associated (MUC1), also called polymorphic epithelial mucin (PEM) or epithelial membrane antigen or EMA, is a mucin encoded by the MUC1 gene in humans. MUC1 is a glycoprotein with extensive O-linked glycosylation of its extracellular domain. Mucins protect the body from infection by pathogen binding to oligosaccharides in the extracellular domain, preventing the pathogen from reaching the cell surface. Overexpression of MUC1 is often associated with colon, breast, ovarian, lung and pancreatic cancers.
Mucin 6 Highly Expressed

Mucin 6, oligomeric mucus/gel-forming, also known as MUC6, is a human gene. In extrahepatic bile duct lesions (biliary IPMNs), MUC2 expression parallels the degree of columnar-cell change and intestinal differentiation, whereas MUC6 is characteristically positive in tumors with a cuboidal-cell pattern and in cases with pyloric or biliary differentiation. Pyloric gland adenomas (of the gallbladder) are consistently positive for MUC6, as well as other pyloric gland markers, such as M-GGMC-1.
Pure Mucinous Cells
Mucinous carcinoma can form along side of other types cancer cells but when it doesn't the cancer is considered 'pure'. Pure mucinous carcinoma is composed of 90–100% mucinous cells.
Mixed Mucinous Cells
Mucinous carcinoma can form along side of other types cancer cells, when this happens, the cancer is referred to as mixed mucinous carcinoma.
Napsin A Highly Expressed

Napsin A is a functional aspartic proteinase, expressed in the cytoplasm of healthy lung parenchyma. It is homologous with the polypeptide TAO2 and involved in maturation of the biologically active surfactant protein B. It also consists of a 38-kDa protein, a single-chain protein expressed in type II pneumocytes, alveolar macrophages, renal tubules, and exocrine glands and ducts in the pancreas. Napsin A may be an alternative marker for primary lung cancer.
White Stools

A white or clay-like stool is caused by a lack of bile, which may indicate a serious underlying problem. Bile is a digestive fluid produced by the liver and stored in the gallbladder. A stool gets its normal brownish color from bile, which is excreted into the small intestine during the digestive process.
Pre-existing Liver Condition
The patient's medical record, or the patient themself, has let the doctor know they have or had a pre-existing liver condition.
Hepatic Encephalopathy

Hepatic encephalopathy is a decline in brain function that occurs as a result of severe liver disease. In this condition, the liver can't adequately remove toxins. This causes a buildup of toxins in the bloodstream, which can lead to brain damage.
Hyperammonemia
Hyperammonemia is a metabolic disturbance characterised by an excess of ammonia in the blood. It is a dangerous condition that may lead to brain injury and death.
Alpha-Fetoprotein Elevated Levels

Alpha-fetoprotein is a protein that in humans is encoded by the AFP gene. The AFP gene is located on the q arm of chromosome 4. AFP is a major plasma protein produced by the yolk sac and the fetal liver during fetal development. AFP is found mainly in liver cancer and nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, which are rare. These are found in the pineal gland in the brain. Some people with cirrhosis or chronic active hepatitis also have higher blood levels of AFP. Like any elevated tumor marker, elevated AFP by itself is not diagnostic, only suggestive.
Hepatocyte Paraffin 1 Antigen Detected

Hepatocyte paraffin 1 is a monoclonal antibody that has been developed specifically to react with hepatocytes in routine formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded surgical pathology tissues. It results in a distinct, granular cytoplasmic staining of hepatocytes but fails to react with bile ducts and nonparenchymal liver cells. The antibody decorates a majority of hepatocellular carcinomas, including fibrolamellar variants. It fails to react with a wide variety of other adult malignancies, with the exception of focal staining in a few gastrointestinal malignancies, including a subpopulation of gastric carcinomas.
Abnormal LFT Results

The patient's Liver Function Test have returned abnormal results, further testing is needed to help determine the possible cause. Abnormal liver function test results don't always indicate liver disease and may instead be a result of a number of circumstances.
Acute Liver Failure
Acute liver failure (ALF) is a rare syndrome defined by a rapid decline in hepatic function.
Cellular Rejection

Cellular Rejection occurs when the body's blood cells identify a transplanted organ as foreign object and begin mounting an army of cells to attack it. Having rejection does not mean that the patient will lose their transplanted organ, but it is extremely important that rejection is diagnosed and treated as soon as possible.
Internal Bleeding
Bleeding inside the body, particularly in the chest cavity, stomach cavity or muscles, that may be caused by major trauma, surgery or some unknown complication.
Hemodynamic Instability
Hemodynamic instability occurs when there's abnormal or unstable blood pressure, which can cause inadequate blood flow. This symptom can be life-threatening and may require ICU intervention.
Rupture of a Lesion
A lesion or tumour inside the patient has ruptured. This is associated with life-threatening internal bleeding.
Facial Nerve Paralysis

Facial nerve paralysis is characterised by facial weakness, usually only in one side of the face, with other symptoms possibly including loss of taste, hyperacusis and decreased salivation and tear secretion.
Dysplasia
Dysplasia (Cytologic Atypia) the presence of cells of an abnormal type within a tissue, which may signify a stage preceding the development of cancer.
Elevated Epidermoid Cell Count
Testing has detected an abnormally high level of epidermoid cells. This can indicate a worse prognosis or more developed cancer.
